title: 110_hr3648
content: The "Mortgage Forgiveness Debt Relief Act of 2007" excludes discharges of indebtedness on a principal residence from gross income. The Mortgage Forgiveness Debt Relief Act of 2007 excludes qualified principal residence indebtedness discharged before January 1, 2010 from gross income. Additionally, the amount excluded from gross income reduces the basis of the taxpayer's principal residence. The Mortgage Forgiveness Debt Relief Act of 2007 excludes qualified principal residence indebtedness from gross income, reducing the taxpayer's basis in their principal residence. Qualified principal residence indebtedness includes acquisition debt up to $2,000,000. Exceptions apply for loan discharges unrelated to the taxpayer's financial condition. The Mortgage Forgiveness Debt Relief Act of 2007 excludes qualified principal residence indebtedness from gross income, reducing the taxpayer's basis in their principal residence. Exceptions apply for loan discharges unrelated to the taxpayer's financial condition. The discharge of a loan is not covered if it is due to services performed for the lender or other factors not directly related to the value of the residence or the taxpayer's financial condition. The amendments made by this section apply to discharges of indebtedness on or after January 1, 2007, with the principal residence exclusion taking precedence over the insolvency exclusion unless elected otherwise. SEC. 3 extends the treatment of mortgage insurance premiums as interest until December 31, 2010. SEC. 4 provides alternative tests for qualifying as a cooperative housing corporation. SEC. 4 amends the definition of a cooperative housing corporation in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 by setting requirements for gross income, property usage, and expenditures during the taxable year. The amendment to the definition of a cooperative housing corporation in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 sets requirements for gross income, property usage, and expenditures during the taxable year, with an effective date for taxable years ending after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 5. EXCLUSION FROM INCOME FOR BENEFITS PROVIDED TO VOLUNTEER FIREFIGHTERS AND EMERGENCY MEDICAL RESPONDERS. An amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 introduces a new section, SEC. 139B, which excludes benefits provided to volunteer firefighters and emergency medical responders from gross income. In the case of qualified volunteer emergency response organization members, gross income excludes qualified State and local tax benefits and qualified payments. Deductions and expenses for services are limited to avoid double benefits. Definitions for qualified state and local tax benefits are provided. The curr_chunk defines "qualified state and local tax benefit" as a reduction or rebate of certain taxes provided by a State for services as a member of a volunteer emergency response organization. It also defines "qualified payment" as any payment provided by a State for services as a member of such organization. The curr_chunk explains that a taxpayer can receive a tax benefit for performing services as a member of a qualified volunteer emergency response organization, with a limit of $30 per month. A qualified organization provides firefighting or emergency medical services and is required by the state or political subdivision to do so. The curr_chunk states that the section regarding tax benefits for qualified volunteer emergency response organizations will not apply after December 31, 2010. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for such part. The amendments regarding benefits for volunteer firefighters and emergency medical responders will be effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2007. Additionally, a clarification is made regarding student housing eligibility for low-income housing credit. The amendment in section 7 applies to housing credit amounts allocated and buildings placed in service before or after the enactment date. It also addresses the joint return limitation for capital gains exclusion on post-marriage sales of principal residences by surviving spouses. The amendment in section 7 of the Internal Revenue Code applies to post-marriage sales of principal residences by surviving spouses. It allows for a higher capital gains exclusion of $500,000 if the sale occurs within 2 years of the spouse's death. This amendment is effective for sales or exchanges after December 31, 2007. SEC. 8. Modification of penalty for failure to file partnership returns; limitation on disclosure. Extension of Time Limitation for filing partnership returns is increased from 5 months to 12 months. Penalty amount for failure to file partnership returns is increased from $50 to $85. Limitation on disclosure of taxpayer returns to partners, S Corporation shareholders, trust beneficiaries, and estate beneficiaries is amended under section 6103(e) of the Internal Revenue Code. The amendment limits the disclosure of taxpayer information in partnership, S corporation, trust, or estate returns. The effective date of the amendment is the enactment date of the Act. SEC. 9. PENALTY FOR FAILURE TO FILE S CORPORATION RETURNS. Amends the Internal Revenue Code to include a penalty for failure to file S corporation returns. Penalty for failure to file S corporation returns under section 6037 includes a penalty for late filing or incomplete information, with a monthly penalty not exceeding 12 months, unless due to reasonable cause. The penalty amount is $85 multiplied by the number of shareholders in the S corporation. The penalty for failure to file S corporation returns under section 6037 is $85 per month multiplied by the number of shareholders. The penalty is assessed against the S corporation and deficiency procedures do not apply for the assessment or collection of this penalty. The amendments made by this section apply to S corporation returns required to be filed after the enactment of this Act. The percentage for corporate estimated taxes is increased by 1.50 percentage points.
